MLRA_2015_5_348.JUDGMENT_NAME: TAN POH THIAM v. INDUSTRIAL COURT OF MALAYSIA & ANOR
MLRA_2015_5_348.JUDGE_NAME: Mohd Hishamudin Yunus, Linton Albert, Hamid Sultan Abu Backer JJCA

p.i: Labour Law: Employment - Dismissal - Dismissal on grounds of misconduct - Unfair dismissal - Whether allegations raised in show-cause papers amounted to misconduct - Whether allegations covered by doctrine of condonation - Whether High Court erred in making such orders without hearing interested parties

Labour Law: Industrial Court - Award - Award dismissing complaint of unfair dismissal - Industrial Court failing to consider whether charges against employee amounted to misconduct in law - Industrial Court failing to carry out balancing exercise consistent with statutory requirements of justice, equity and good conscience - Whether Industrial Court failed to apply law and legal principles - Whether Industrial Court committed grave error of law which warranted that decision be quashed

HEADNOTE.p: The appellant was the sales' general manager with the 2nd respondent. There were no complaints about his work or performance until he received a show-cause letter from the Managing Director, alleging various breaches purportedly amounting to serious misconduct. The appellant replied to the show-cause letter explaining that he was not at fault, and he was not the decision maker in respect of certain decisions complained of, and he further stated that all related matters in respect of the show-cause letter could be resolved through discussions and dialogue. The 2nd respondent did not respond to the appellant's reply but immediately held an enquiry where the appellant was dismissed on five charges framed against him. The matter was referred to the Industrial Court which upheld the dismissal. The appellant applied for judicial review of the award to the High Court. The High Court affirmed the decision of the Industrial Court, and the appellant thus appealed to the Court of Appeal.

(1) The show-cause letter was not similar to the notice of domestic inquiry. The charges in the domestic inquiry were similar to the charges found in the Industrial Court. The Industrial Court was not clear in its finding on the charges. The Industrial Court said that the first and third charges were proven but at the end found the appellant guilty on the first and fourth charges. (paras 21-22)

(2) Having scrutinised the show-cause letter, the appellant's reply to the showcause letter, the outcome of the charges in the domestic enquiry as well as the Industrial Court award, this court was of the view that the allegations, even if true, did not amount to misconduct and did not warrant dismissal with just cause and excuse. Some of the allegations, even if true, were stale and/or sterile allegations which could be said to have been engulfed by the doctrine of condonation. (para 28(i)-(ii))

(3) The Industrial Court had failed to first decide whether the complaint and/ or charges amounted to misconduct in law, before proceeding to find the appellant liable. Further, the Industrial Court failed to carry out a balancing exercise of the conduct of the parties and their respective responsibilities, taking into account the doctrine of condonation as well as the proportionality principle, consistent with the statutory requirement of justice, equity and good conscience anchored in s 30 of the Industrial Relations Act 1967. In failing to do so the Industrial Court had failed to apply the law and legal principles and in consequence had committed a grave error of law which warranted that the decision be quashed. (para 28(iii))

JUDGMENT.p: [1] The appellant (employee) appeals against the decision of the learned High Court Judge who refused to quash the award of the Industrial Court which dismissed the appellant's application against the dismissal by the 2nd respondent (employer) based on just cause or excuse relating to allegations of misconduct. We heard the appeal on 13 November 2014 and upon hearing the submission, we allowed the appeal. My learned brothers Mohd Hishamudin Yunus JCA and Linton Albert JCA have read the judgment and agreed the same. This is our judgment.

[2] It must be strictly observed that industrial law jurisprudence does not permit all forms of unsatisfactory conduct or poor performance or negligence to be labeled as misconduct. There are a number of case laws here as well as in other recognised jurisdictions that explain what act or conduct amount to misconduct or will not satisfy the threshold.

[3] An industrial tribunal properly appraised of the facts must not succumb to any allegation of misconduct, if the acts complained of do not qualify as misconduct, or if the circumstances leading to allegation of misconduct do not warrant dismissal on the ground of just cause or excuse, taking into consideration the proportionality principle advocated in the case laws.

[4] Industrial law jurisprudence does not permit any form of oppressive conduct on the part of an employer having the objective of dismissing the employee on "just cause or excuse" based on trivial allegations; based on matters that could have been dealt with appropriately with proper operating system or management system instead of taking drastic steps to dismiss the employee. The Industrial Court in the Malaysian context is obliged to do a balancing exercise taking into account such factors as the nature of the complaint the conduct of the employer, the operating and management system that is in place, the reason advanced by the employee as well as his conduct, and the gravity of the allegation; in order to ascertain whether the employee's act or omission qualifies as a misconduct to attract s 20 of Industrial Relations Act 1967 (IRA 1967). The proposition is fortified by s 30 of IRA 1967.
[5] It is now well established that in exercising the jurisdiction and power under s 20 of the IRA 1967, the duty of the Industrial Court is two-fold, namely:

Failure to determine these issues on the merits would be a jurisdictional error which merits intervention by the High Court. [See Milan Auto Sdn Bhd v. Wong Seh Yen [1995] 2 MLRA 23; [1995] 3 MLJ 537; [1995] 4 CLJ 449; [1996] 1 AMR 049].

[6] The starting point and the key to decide whether the situation attracts s 20 is for the Industrial Court to determine whether the complaint qualifies as misconduct, taking into consideration all the circumstances and facts.
[7] The term 'misconduct' is not defined in IRA 1967. The Law Lexicon by P Ramantha Aiyar (Reprint 1992) defines misconduct inter alia as follows:

[8] In India there are some statutory guidelines as to what acts and omissions will be treated as misconduct. The learned author OP Malhotra, The Law of Industrial Disputes in 5th edn at pp 891 and 892 says:

[9] Some of the key words above are 'willful', 'habitual', 'riotous', frequent repetition', 'inciting others', etc; to show the gravity of the conduct. In the instant case, we note that none of the allegation by way of show cause letter or in the domestic inquiry or the charges framed in the Industrial Court attracts the key words or any criminal element including fraud.

[10] The Indian cases do not permit the employers to allege misconduct when the standing orders are silent and the courts do not leave it to the vagaries of the management to say ex post facto that a certain act exposes the workman to a penalty. [See Glaxo Laboratories (I) Ltd v. The Presiding Officer, Labour Court [1983] Lab IC 1909; OP Malhotra, 5 edn at p 892].

[11] It is well established that appellate courts will not interfere with finding of facts of the Industrial Court. This proposition is subject to the acid test employed in the decision of the Federal Court in R Rama Chandran v. Industrial Court Of Malaysia & Anor & Anor [1996] 1 MELR 71; [1996] 1 MLRA 725; [1997] 1 MLJ 145; [1997] 1 CLJ 147; [1997] 1 AMR 433, which firmly established that the decision of the Industrial Court is susceptible to judicial review on the grounds of (i) illegality; (ii) irrationality; (iii) procedural impropriety; and (iv) possibly proportionality under which the courts are clothed with powers to scrutinise the decision not only for process but also for substance:

[12] Decided cases after Rama Chandran had further clarified the legal position that where the facts do not support the conclusion arrived at by the Industrial Court or in arriving at its findings, or where the Industrial Court took into account irrelevant matters, or failed to take into account irrelevant matters, such findings are always amenable to judicial review. [See Ranjit Kaur S Gopal Singh v. Hotel Excelsior (M) Sdn Bhd [2012] 1 MELR 129; [2010] 5 MLRA 696; [2011] 1 ILJ 479; [2010] 6 MLJ 1; [2010] 4 ILR 475; [2010] 8 CLJ 629; [2011] 3 AMR 38].

[13] The Federal Court in a recent decision in Norizan Bakar v. Panzana Enterprise Sdn Bhd [2014] 1 MELR 1; [2013] 6 MLRA 613; [2014] 1 ILJ 278; [2013] 6 MLJ 605; [2013] 4 ILR 477; [2013] 9 CLJ 409; [2013] 6 AMR 338, further affirmed that the doctrine of proportionality applies to cases under s 20 of the Industrial Relations Act 1967. The Federal Court referred to s 30(5) and (6) as well as Item 5 of the Second Schedule of the Industrial Relations Act 1967 and held that the doctrine of proportionality of punishment is already inbuilt into the Industrial Relations Act 1967:

[14] It must also be noted that industrial law jurisprudence, under the doctrine of condonation, does not permit the employer to rely on stale and sterile charges based on past facts. The principle of condonation was lucidly explained by the Federal Court in Public Services Commission Malaysia & Anor v. Vickneswary Rm Santhivelu [2008] 2 MLRA 273; [2008] 6 MLJ 1; [2008] 6 CLJ 573, where Zaki Tun Azmi PCA (as he then was) held as follows at p 284 of the report:

[15] The appellant was a General Manager of sales with the 2nd respondent (hereinafter shall be referred to as 'the respondent') company. He began his employment from 1 August 2002. There was no complaint about his work or performance until he received a show cause letter from the Managing Director, alleging various breaches purportedly amounting to serious misconduct. In evidence, the appellant alleged that the show cause was issued because he had a misunderstanding with the brother of the Managing Director. [See A/R pp 657 and 606]. It is also not in dispute that there were other officers of the company, including the Managing Director, who were directly or indirectly responsible and also liable to answer to the show cause letter per se. The terms of the appellant's letter of appointment also do not have any nexus to the show cause letter. The appellant did reply to the show cause letter explaining that he was not at fault, and he was not the decision maker and all related matters in respect of the show cause letter can be resolved through discussion and dialogue [Emphasis Added].

[16] The respondent did not respond to the appellant's reply letter. The respondent immediately held an enquiry and dismissed the appellant on five charges framed against him. The reply to the show cause letter was part of the evidence but the Industrial Court did not consider his explanation in the letter per se but only considered his testimony.
